p: Camels harbor several tick species, and some are important vectors of pathogens; protozoal, virus, and bacteria spp. cause tick paralysis and toxicosis (see above). However, their role of transmitting these pathogens to camelids seems to be much less important than it is to other animals and humans (Bornstein 2002). Lately Alkhurma hemorrhagic fever virus (AHFV) was isolated in an Ornithodoros savignyi, the sand sampan, from Saudi Arabia (Charrel et al. 2007). This soft tick has a wide distribution in arid lands and may lay dormant for long periods during harsh conditions. The tick infests many different hosts including camels as well as humans. The AHFV causes an extremely severe hemorrhagic fever in humans with a case fatality rate of >30 %. About 20 human cases have been diagnosed with the infection in Saudi Arabia (Charrel et al. 2007). The authors associate these or some of these cases with tick bite history.
